results.title: Don't label me
results.creator_credit: Richard Ballentine, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Douglas Leiterman
results.brief_description: Examines the subject of neutralism, or non-alignment, as preached and practised by Dr. Cheddi Jagan, Prime Minister of the former colony of British Guiana, now emerging from colonization, who admires Castro, but also pleads, “Don’t try to pin any labels on me!”

results.title: Don't knock the ox
results.creator_credit: William Canning, ONF | NFB and Tony Ianzelo
results.brief_description: The International Ox Pull, highlight of the Bridgewater, Nova Scotia, annual fair, is a holdover from the pioneer past when oxen cleared the land and tilled the soil. That these great beasts of burden have lost none of their pulling power is well demonstrated as they drag tons of weight loaded on sleds (the winner pulls up to six tons). Competing teams come from various parts of the Maritimes and the northeastern United States.

results.title: Don't just stand there coughing
results.creator_credit: Gus Howard, Seethru Film Productions, South Australian Film Corporation and Craig Lahiff
results.brief_description: This film is designed to show the causes and effects of air pollution. It offers possible remedies to improve the quality of the air we breathe. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Don't give up on me
results.brief_description: A look at the child abuse problem from the desperate parents’ point of view. Barbara, a mother of two small children, is accused of abusive behaviour and in danger of having her baby taken from her by the courts. We see Barbara’s State-assigned case worker, struggling to help the distraught mother come to grips with her problem. An adapted case history which uses scenes from an actual counselling workshop for child abuse parents.

results.title: Don't call me girlie
results.creator_credit: Hilary Furlong, Andree Wright and Stewart Young
results.brief_description: A survey of the role of women in Australian cinema from the beginning to 1940 using interviews and archival footage. Prominence is given to the collaboration between Lottie Lyell and Raymond Longford, the McDonagh sisters (whose 1933 production Two Minutes Silence was the last Australian feature directed by a woman until My Brilliant Career in 1979) and the careers of actresses Louise Lovely, Helen Twelvetrees and Shirley Ann Richards. Includes extracts from “A Girl of the Bush” (1921), “The Cheaters” (1929), “The Squatter’s Daughter” (1933), “The Silence of Dean Maitland” (1937) and “Dad and Dave Come To Town” (1938).

results.title: Don't bother to knock
results.creator_credit: Julian Blaustein, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Roy Baker
results.brief_description: Don’t bother to knock features a rarely seen dark side to Marilyn Monroe’s usual performances. While babysitting in a hotel, she begins a flirtation with one of the guests (Richard Widmark). He is on the rebound after breaking up with his girlfriend (Anne Bancroft), and is willingly seduced by the babysitter. When the baby awakes and disturbs their lovemaking, Monroe becomes deranged and terrorizes both the man and child. The film gives a chilling glimpse into the mind of a homicidal personality.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julian Blaustein, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Roy Baker

results.title: Don't be the last to know (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Aviva Ziegler, Film Australia and Stephen Ramsey
results.brief_description: Introduced by Mike Willesee - this video provides an in-depth look at two Australian families and their fight against drug addiction. Typical families with day to day problems like everyone else - until a serious drug problem surfaced. Addicts and their families speak frankly about their frustration, confusion and the courage needed to fight back. Essential viewing for all parents.
